review.title: Decentralized Data Fusion and Active Sensing with Mobile Sensors for Modeling and Predicting Spatiotemporal Traffic Phenomena
review.abstract: The problem of modeling and predicting spatiotemporal traffic phenomena over an urban road network is important to many traffic applications such as detecting and forecasting congestion hotspots. This paper presents a decentralized data fusion and active sensing (D2FAS) algorithm for mobile sensors to actively explore the road network to gather and assimilate the most informative data for predicting the traffic phenomenon. We analyze the time and communication complexity of D2FAS and demonstrate that it can scale well with a large number of observations and sensors. We provide a theoretical guarantee on its predictive performance to be equivalent to that of a sophisticated centralized sparse approximation for the Gaussian process (GP) model: The computation of such a sparse approximate GP model can thus be parallelized and distributed among the mobile sensors (in a Google-like MapReduce paradigm), thereby achieving efficient and scalable prediction. We also theoretically guarantee its active sensing performance that improves under various practical environmental conditions. Empirical evaluation on real-world urban road network data shows that our D2FAS algorithm is significantly more time-efficient and scalable than state-of-the-art centralized algorithms while achieving comparable predictive performance.

sections.heading: 2.2 Subset of Data Approximation
sections.text: Although the GP is an effective predictive model, it faces a practical limitation of the cubic time complexity in the number of observations that can be observed from the calculation of the posterior distribution (i.e., (1) and (2), which requires a reversal of the covariance matrix (DD) and the unforeseen time. If the GP prediction is expected to be large, it cannot be performed in real time. For practical application, we need to resort to a mathematically cheaper approximate GP prediction. a simple method of approximation is to select only a subset U of the total set of observed street segments (i.e., the U-D) to calculate the subsequent distribution of measurements to any set of Y V\ D unobserved street segments. Such a subset of data (SoD) is an approximation method that produces the following predictive UU distribution method closely reminiscent of the GP prediction.

sections.heading: 3 Decentralized Data Fusion
sections.text: In this section, we will discuss the decentralized data fusion algorithms of our D2FAS algorithms, which distribute the computational load between the mobile sensors to achieve an efficient and scalable approximate GP prediction. Intuition of our decentralized data fusion algorithms is as follows: Each of the mobile sensors constructs a local summary of the observations made along its own path in the road network and communicates its local summary to each other sensor. Then, it assimilates the local summaries of the other sensors into a globally unified summary, which is used for predicting the traffic phenomenon as well as for active sensitization.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: Analytical and empirical results have shown that our D2FAS algorithm is much more time-saving and more scalable as the number of observations and sensors increases, while delivering a prediction performance similar to the most advanced centralized active capture associated with FGP and SoD. Therefore, D2FAS is handy for deployment in a large mobile sensor network to achieve durable and accurate traffic modelling and forecasting. In our future work, we assume that each sensor can only communicate locally with its neighbors (rather than assuming full communication) and can develop a distributed data fusion approach for efficient and scalable safe GP predictions based on D2FAS and consensus filters (Olfati-Saber, 2005).
